q: What are some ways to ease pain in the back of your hand?
a: To ease pain in the back of your hand, you can rest your hand, apply ice for 20 minutes every 2-3 hours, take paracetamol, remove jewelry if your hand is swollen, wrap it with a bandage, wear a splint, and gently exercise your hand and fingers to reduce pain and stiffness.

q: Should I use ibuprofen for hand pain?
a: It is not recommended to use ibuprofen in the first 48 hours after an injury for hand pain.

q: What can a pharmacist help with regarding hand pain?
a: You can consult a pharmacist for advice on the best painkiller, treatments for common skin problems, and to determine if you need to see a GP for hand pain.

q: When should I see a GP for hand pain?
a: You should see a GP if the pain is stopping you from doing normal activities, if it is getting worse or recurring, if it has not improved after two weeks of home treatment, if you experience tingling or loss of sensation, or if you have diabetes and hand pain.

q: When should I go to an urgent treatment centre or A&E for hand pain?
a: You should go to an urgent treatment centre or A&E if you have severe hand pain, feel faint or dizzy, heard a snap or popping noise during the injury, are unable to move your hand or hold things, have lost feeling in part or all of your hand, or if your hand has changed shape or color. These symptoms might indicate a broken hand.

q: What are some common causes of pain in the back of the hand?
a: Common causes of pain in the back of the hand include bruising or injuring the hand, tendonitis or arthritis, broken bones, ganglion cysts, carpal tunnel syndrome, and conditions like scabies.

q: What are some possible causes if I have pain, swelling, and stiffness that lasts a long time in the back of my hand?
a: Pain, swelling, and stiffness that lasts a long time in the back of your hand may be due to tendonitis or arthritis.

q: What could be the cause of sudden, sharp pain, swelling, and a popping or snapping sound during an injury?
a: Sudden, sharp pain, swelling, and a popping or snapping sound during an injury could indicate a broken bone in the hand.

q: What might be the cause of a smooth lump near a joint or tendon that is painful?
a: A smooth lump near a joint or tendon that is painful could be a ganglion cyst.

q: What could be causing aching pain, numbness or pins and needles, a weak thumb, or difficulty gripping?
a: Aching pain, numbness or pins and needles, a weak thumb, or difficulty gripping could be symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
